ygData.subject: Re: [neat] I think this guy has rediscovered Novelty search
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all, Can anyone explain this technique in a language we all can understand? I was actually interviewed for that InsideScience story, and as you can see

Subject: Re: [neat] I think this guy has rediscovered Novelty search

Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello all,

Can anyone explain this technique in a language we all can unde=
rstand? I was actually interviewed for that InsideScience story, and as you=
 can see in the interview, I basically say "Sounds interesting, but I don't=
 understand how it works."

Two questions:
1) Is it just that they picked p=
roblems carefully such that maximizing entropy is the solution we intuitive=
ly think is interesting (e.g. balancing the pole)? They seems to have an im=
pressive array of results (e.g. pacman and picking stocks): why is it that =
the behavior we think it interesting is the one that maximizes entropy? For=
 example, tool use could be involved in opening and eating a coconut, but I=
 don't think that maximized potential future actions (unless it does by kee=
ping you alive). If you tried this on most problems would it just work, or =
was the brilliance of the paper carefully constructing the problems to work=
 with this approach?  Here is a video showing the pac-man and stock results=
: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DrZB8TNaG-ik

2) More importantly: how do=
 they figure out what actions maximize the number of future actions? That s=
eems like a very difficult problem (see my coconut example), and I don't ge=
t what their algorithm is to figure it out. How did the system figure out t=
hat balancing the pole gives you the most options in the future, for exampl=
e?


Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Computer Science
Univers=
ity of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com

On Apr 24, 2013, at 9:16 P=
M, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:

> 
> 
> Hi Greg, thanks to both you=
 and Colin (in his prior post) for pointing out his work. As a non-objectiv=
e type of behavioral search, it is indeed reminiscent of novelty search. Li=
ke both of you I'm not really sure if the idea is that new, though it's not=
 entirely the same as anything else either. Another question is whether it =
has any advantage over easier-to-understand ideas like searching for novelt=
y. A couple concepts that remind me a bit of this work outside novelty sear=
ch include "homeokinesis" (http://robot.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/videos/) =
and "Maximum Entropy Inverse Reinforcement Learning" (which at least sounds=
 quite similar) (http://www.aaai.org/Papers/AAAI/2008/AAAI08-227.pdf)
> 
> =
Best,
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Greg" <greg_barton@...> w=
rote:
> >
> > http://www.insidescience.org/content/physicist-proposes-new-w=
ay-think-about-intelligence/987
> > 
> > From the article: 'Entropica's int=
elligent behavior emerges from the "physical process of trying to capture a=
s many future histories as possible," said Wissner-Gross.' 
> > 
> > Fairly=
 close to searching for novelty.
> >
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_317A8E1E-9ED1-471F-A065-D1C3135FC517

<div style=3D"background-=
color: #fff;">
<span style=3D"display:none"> </span>



    <div id=3D=
"ygrp-text"><p><br>
<br>
Hi Greg, thanks to both you and Colin (in his prio=
r post) for pointing out his work.  As a non-objective type of behavioral s=
earch, it is indeed reminiscent of novelty search.  Like both of you I'm no=
t really sure if the idea is that new, though it's not entirely the same as=
 anything else either.  Another question is whether it has any advantage ov=
er easier-to-understand ideas like searching for novelty. A couple concepts=
 that remind me a bit of this work outside novelty search include "homeokin=
esis" (<a href=3D"http://robot.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/videos/">http://ro=
bot.informatik.uni-leipzig.de/videos/</a>) and "Maximum Entropy Inverse Rei=
nforcement Learning" (which at least sounds quite similar) (<a href=3D"http=
://www.aaai.org/Papers/AAAI/2008/AAAI08-227.pdf">http://www.aaai.org/Papers=
/AAAI/2008/AAAI08-227.pdf</a>)<br>
<br>
Best,<br>
<br>
ken<br>
<br>
--- In =
<a href=3D"mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, "Greg" =

> <a href=3D"http://www.insi=
descience.org/content/physicist-proposes-new-way-think-about-intelligence/9=
87">http://www.insidescience.org/content/physicist-proposes-new-way-think-a=
bout-intelligence/987</a><br>
> <br>
> From the article: 'Entropica's=
 intelligent behavior emerges from the "physical process of trying to captu=
re as many future histories as possible," said Wissner-Gross.'  <br>
> <=
br>
> Fairly close to searching for novelty.<br>
><br>
<br>
</p>
